Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend on their way to the airport calls, thinking they left their passport at home, and asks if you can check and bring it to them right away.
Situation2: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Story:
My phone buzzed just as I was counting the money I’d saved for Hajj, the trip I’d been dreaming of for years. It was Samir, my closest friend, his voice tight with panic. “I think I left my passport at home. Can you check and bring it to the airport? My flight’s in two hours.” I glanced at the envelope of cash on my desk—the money I’d carefully set aside, resisting every temptation, every unexpected expense, just so I could finally fulfill my religious duty this year. My friends were already booking their tickets, and I knew if I dipped into my savings now, I might not be able to go with them.

But Samir was always there for me, and I knew he’d do the same if our roles were reversed. The expectation to help a friend in crisis weighed heavily on me, but so did the sacred obligation I felt as a Muslim to perform Hajj. My heart pounded as I stared at the envelope, torn between loyalty to my friend and my longing to answer the call to pilgrimage.
